sections.text:

Rational design of two-dimensional nanomaterials for lithium–sulfur batteries
Milan Jana,†a Rui Xu, †bc Xin-Bing Cheng, †d Jeong Seok Yeon,a Jae Min Park,a Jia-Qi Huang, *c Qiang Zhang *d and Ho Seok Park ‡*ae
The inherent technical challenges of lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have arisen from the intrinsic redox
electrochemistry occurring on the Li and S electrodes, which can significantly deteriorate the S utiliza-
tion and life cycle. Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials composed of atomic or near-atomic thickness
with infinite lateral dimensions have been proven to be meritorious as emerging materials for energy
storage applications due to their unique structures, remarkable physical properties, and tunable surface
chemistry. Herein, we argue that surface functionalization or heteroatom doping of 2D materials,
hybridization with other nanostructured materials (0D quantum dots, 1D nanotubes/nanowires, and
other 2D nanosheets), and finally architecting into 3D structures along with the advantages of 2D
building blocks can open up new opportunities for Li–S batteries. We also focus on the future directions
of Li–S batteries in the design of S cathodes and separators utilizing the intrinsic and extrinsic properties
of 2D nanomaterials.
Broader context Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries are considered as cost-effective and high-energy-density batteries compared to the current lithium-ion batteries. The practical applications of Li–S batteries are still restricted by technical challenges arising from the intrinsic charge storage electrochemistry and the properties of the materials. The S cathode is restricted by redox shuttling as well as deprived electrical conductivity, resulting in low S utilization, poor cyclability and self-discharge causing battery failure. Low S loading and the high value of the electrolyte to S ratio restrict the engineering of practically viable high energy density Li–S batteries. Recent advances in 2D materials and their modifications have been exploited to resolve the aforementioned problems. We describe a comprehensive overview focusing on functional 2D materials for the cathode, and separators of Li–S batteries. Along with intrinsic properties and the unique surface chemistries of the 2D nanomaterials, their extrinsic properties are obtained from hierarchical architecturing and hybridization with other 0D, 1D, and 2D nanomaterials. Assembling 2D building blocks into practical bulk forms such as film, fiber, powder, and monolith, 2D materials are used as active materials, host, protection layers, and reaction promoters. Finally, deep insights and perspectives into the current challenges and future directions for practical Li–S batteries are provided.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The exploration of energy-storage devices with very high energy density and low cost far beyond the current lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) has been motivated by the rapidly growing demand for renewable energy with sustainability and the emerging markets of future electronics and electric vehicles.1–5 Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries configured with light-weight lithium (Li) anodes and earth-abundant and high-capacity sulfur (S) cathodes are considered as promising candidates to accomplish such cost-effective and high-energy-density batteries.6–10 On the one hand, a Li metal anode renders a high theoretical specific capacity of 3860 mA h g 1 with the lowest redox potential of 3.040 V (vs. the standard hydrogen electrode).11–13 On the other hand, low-cost S exhibits a high theoretical capacity of 1675 mA h g 1
in light of its small atomic number and multi-electron conversion chemistry with Li ions.6–8 Consequently, Li–S batteries provide a great opportunity to achieve higher theoretical energy density based on the overall redox reaction, 2Li + S = Li2S, as compared to LIBs, delivering gravimetric and volumetric values of 2500 W h kg 1 and 2800 W h L 1, respectively.2,3,14

It is expected that Li–S batteries will provide gravimetric energy density of 400–600 W h kg 1, which is around twice that of LIBs, along with the volumetric energy density of 700 W h L 1 for a fully packaged system. Despite these promising features of Li–S batteries, their real-operation values of energy density and cyclability on a large scale cannot satisfy the requirements for practical Li–S batteries.2 As shown in Fig. 1, Li–S batteries have technical challenges arising from the intrinsic redox electrochemistry occurring on positive and negative electrodes and properties of active materials as follows. The S cathode is limited by redox shuttling and parasitic reactions of soluble polysulfides as well as low electrical conductivity of S and insolubility of Li2S. 3 This will be addressed in more detail in Section 3. A low S loading (areal) or low S content (%) is another obstacle in the path toward practically viable Li–S batteries with high energy density. For instance, an areal capacity of 4 mA cm 2 is needed for LIBs to be commercially viable for future electric vehicles. Considering the lower average voltage of Li–S (2.2 V) as compared to that of LIBs (3.5 V), the areal capacity should be at least 6 mA h cm 2 for Li–S batteries. The required S loading is estimated to be around 3.58 mg cm 2 according to the theoretical specific capacity of S. Because in practice, it is very difficult to achieve the theoretical capacity of S, areal loading more than 5 mg cm 2 with S utilization of 70–80% is needed. The high value of the electrolyte to S (E/S) ratio, which is more than 10 mL mg 1 (according to the weight of S) in most cases, can prevent the achievement of the high energy density of Li–S batteries.5,10 Accordingly, an S loading of 45.0 mg S cm 2, having an E/S ratio of o3.0 mL mg 1, is the peripheral condition for achieving the energy density of 4500 W h kg 1 in the fully packaged Li–S cells.5 Considering that commercial LIBs have an electrolyte/active material ratio of 1 mL mg 1, the large amount of electrolyte increases the cost of Li–S cells. The use of a low E/S ratio unavoidably brings up several problems. The low E/S ratio increases the viscosity and the electronic conductivity of the electrolyte, causing sluggish redox kinetics. Reducing the E/S ratio to the solubility limit (equivalent to 3.8 mL mg 1) of the electrolyte causes precipitation of Li2S2/Li2S from the electrolyte without binding to conductive supports. Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials that are comprised of atomic or near-atomic thickness with infinite lateral dimension have received significant attention as emerging energy storage materials.18–22 The energy storage behaviors of 2D nanomaterials are associated with their unique structure, surface chemistry, and remarkable physical properties.19,20 A large family of 2D graphene and beyond with numerous combinations of compositions and crystalline structures collectively covers a broad range of physical and chemical properties that will be discussed in Section 2.19–24 Along with intrinsic properties and structures, unexpected properties and new functionalities can be extrinsically obtained by controlling the hierarchical architecture and hybrid compositions.20–24 Hierarchical architectures in multiscale structures can be assembled by using 2D nanomaterials as soft building blocks, providing integrative structural features on both micro- and macroscopic scales.25,26 By utilizing 2D materials as either major or minor counterparts, hybrid compositions can be delicately controlled to interact with other 0D, 1D, and 2D nanomaterials.20,25 Such various controllable properties and structures allow 2D materials to be applied for nearly every element of Li–S batteries such as anodes, cathodes, and separators. They can also be used as the active material, host, protection layer, conductive additive, and reaction promoter as shown in Fig. 1. 2D materials having elevated surface area, tunable porous structure, and excellent electrochemical stability can be designed as highly loaded S hosts. S hosts composed of highly conductive channels can overcome the sluggish redox kinetics of the Li–S battery having low E/S ratios. The introduction of a 2D reaction promoter can accelerate the reaction rate to adjust lethargic kinetics and finally reduce the irreversible loss of S. 2D polar materials can adsorb the LiPSs and result in low self-discharge during the resting time. 2D materials with different oxygen functionalities, as demonstrated by graphene oxide (GO), can provide chemical interactions to prevent LiPSs diffusion during rest.27,28
Although there are some review articles about the energy storage applications of 2D nanomaterials,20,21,24–26,35 a comprehensive review covering all aspects of 2D nanomaterials regarding Li–S battery applications has not yet been published. Moreover, all of the review articles about Li–S batteries have summarized Li anodes, S cathodes, and separators, respectively, and have not comprehensively focused on the chemical approaches based on 2D materials to solve all issues.3,6,10,11,14,17,18 For instance, Liu et al. reviewed the use of nanostructured metal oxides and sulfides as Li–S cathodes for high S utilization and a long life cycle.3 Cheng et al. focused on the importance and dilemma of the Li anode in Li–S batteries.6 Zhao et al. reviewed anode materials for Li–S batteries, considering the interfacial and structural stability of Li metal powder, Li alloys, and well-designed Li hosts.16 Balach et al. discussed the interaction between the intrinsic properties of metal-based nanomaterials and LiPSs to provide a highperformance Li–S battery.29 Rana et al. reviewed the Li–S battery progress with high S loading to accomplish a feasible areal capacity.30 Zhang et al. highlighted the S infiltration methods, graphene–S configurations, and interaction between S/LiPS and graphene.31 Li et al. focused on the key roles of polysulfides concerning their behavior, and the corresponding impact on
the Li–S batteries.32 Peng et al. addressed the electrochemical energy storage performances of porous-holey 2D nanomaterials in terms of the synthetic procedures, design rule, and beneficial features, summarizing representative works on electrochemical capacitors, LIB, Na-ion batteries, and Li–S and Li–air technologies.33 Ali et al. mainly focused on the suppression of the LiPS shuttling effect using 2D materials as S cathodes, separators/ interlayers, and Li-anodes in Li–S batteries.28 From an engineering perspective, Yang et al. reviewed how to achieve the practical design and parameters for the commercialization of Li–S batteries.34
Herein, for the first time, we review how to resolve some critical challenges of Li–S batteries, considering the practically required parameters (S loading, S content, E/S ratio, and selfdischarge) based on 2D nanomaterials, correlating their structures and properties with the electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries in Section 2. Recent progress and our insight into the design of the S cathode and separator hosted, modified, or promoted by 2D nanomaterials are introduced in Sections 3–5. The practical necessary parameters and estimated cost of the Li–S battery are discussed in Section 5. In Section 6, current impediments and perspectives for future directions in this field will be finally addressed.

As shown in Fig. 2, the 2D nanoscale geometry stacked together by weak van der Waals interactions of atomic interlayers with strong in-plane bonding can provide unique surface features such as high aspect ratio, large surface area, nanoscale confined interlayers, anisotropic transport properties, volume variation, surface exposure of active and polar sites, different edge and basal sites, open porous channels, surface-confined electrochemistry, and unusual electrochemical reactivity.17–19 These unprecedented electrochemical and electronic characteristics are also associated with quantum confinement in the 2D nanoscale surface.32,34 Since electrochemical reactions are initiated from activated sites of the electrode surface, controlling these structural and surface features of 2D nanomaterials is of prime importance to overcome technical challenges arising from the intrinsic conversion chemistry of Li–S batteries (e.g., intermediate polysulfide shuttling and Li dendrites).
Physical and electrochemical properties of 2D nanomaterials can also be tuned by using diverse combinations of constituent components and different crystalline structures as illustrated in Fig. 2. Examples include variation in electronic properties from a zero-overlap semimetal of graphene,22 metals (e.g., NbSe2), 73 semiconductors (e.g., MoS2), 24 and insulators (e.g., BN),24 as well as various surface chemistries having different polarities (e.g., nonpolar graphene and polar graphene oxide) and dangling moieties (e.g., Ti3C2 MXene with O, OH, and F groups).74 The chemical identities of core transition metals and the associated anions can affect the electronic and electrochemical characteristics of 2D nanomaterials, as well as the available oxidation status used as hosts for multi-electron storage (e.g. Mo2+/Mo4+ of MoS2) and binding strength with associated anions. Considering the deterministic effect of the interactions between transition metals and anions on the redox potential, 2D TMDCs including S anions in crystalline frameworks can be used as active materials, not hosts or additives.75 The electrochemical reactivity of 2D nanomaterials is influenced by their crystalline structures and edge effect.75 For instance, the 1T phase and edge sites of MoS2 are more redox-active and electrochemically catalytic than the 2H phase75–77 and the non-defective basal plane to improve their capacity as host materials76 and facilitate the kinetics of solid–solid conversion from Li2S2 to Li2S or vice versa,
64 respectively. These controllable properties of 2D nanomaterials should be considered to resolve critical challenges of Li–S batteries associated with the properties of the materials (e.g., low electronic conductivity of S) and corresponding redox chemistry (e.g., kinetics of polysulfide shuttling and Li2S).
Along with their intrinsic structure and surface chemistry, the extrinsic properties of 2D materials such as ion transport and mechanical integrity can be achieved by assembling 2D building blocks into practical bulk forms such as film, fiber, powder, and monolith as illustrated in Fig. 2.19–21,24,78 Moreover, changes in the multi-scale structures and hybrid compositions of 2D materials assembled in a bulk form can lead to
unexpected properties and new functionalities.19–21,24,78 For instance, the hierarchical architecture constructed by using 2D nanomaterials as soft building blocks provide advantages of 3D macroscopic structure in terms of fast ion transport, easy ion accessibility, and percolated electron transport as a consequence of interconnected transporting pathways.20,21 This structure can facilitate sluggish redox kinetics arising from low electronic conductivities of S (B5 10 28 S m 1) and Li2S (B10
11 S m 1), thereby improving the utilization of active materials and cell efficiency.17
These hierarchical porous structures consist of different pore sizes ranging from micro (o2 nm) through mesopores (2–50 nm) to macropores (450 nm), resulting in multiple characteristics.79,80 Interconnected mesopores and macropores generally created by inter-sheet voids or nanosheet assembly can promote fast ion transport onto active sites,79 while micropores produced by physical and chemical activations offer a large surface area for a high loading and trapping of S.81 Moreover, the huge free space and elasticity of 3D macroporous frameworks provide a buffering effect of the host on the volume expansion of S (80%) and Li.13
Hybrids of 2D nanomaterials with other nanostructured materials such as 0D quantum dots, 1D nanotubes and nanorods, and 2D nanosheets can provide synergistic properties and multi-functionalities of two or more constitutive nanomaterials interacting together.44,82–84 Multifunctional hosts (with host, conductive, and promoter characteristics) and protective layers (with adsorptive, conductive, and promoting characteristics) can be exemplified by graphene–CoS2 and TiO2–CNT paper, respectively.44,84 These hybrids can be further architectured into hierarchical and more complex structures such as hollow core–shell, nano-bubble, double-shelled nanocages, nanoboxes, nanoframes, yolk cells, nano-capsules, and so on.84–86 Such various controllable properties and structures of 2D materials provide a chemical strategy for the rational design of the anode, cathode, and separator of practical Li–S batteries as illustrated in Fig. 2. As discussed in this section, 2D nanomaterials have broad implications in the properties of materials and structures required for Li–S batteries and offer significant opportunities to resolve key corresponding issues. Their correlations and chemical strategies are addressed in more detail in Sections 3–5, focusing on the cathode, separator and practically required parameters respectively.

The S host is necessary for efficient and stable utilization in a manner similar to the Li metal host because only S itself cannot be used as a cathode due to its low electronic conductivity, the dissolution of LiPS, and volume expansion. sections.heading: 3.1 2D materials as hosting S active materials
sections.text:
Motivated by the breakthrough using mesoporous carbons,18 graphene and carbon nanosheets have been investigated as large-surface-area conductive 2D host materials. Although they possess a large specific area, good electronic conductivity, and mechanical and electrochemical stabilities, their external mesoporosity and non-polar surface failed in maintaining initial capacity over long cycles and high-energy efficiency. Ji et al. demonstrated that 1 g of host material with 1 cm3 g 1 of pore volume can accommodate 1.66 g of Li2S with a density of 1.66 g cm 3, thereby hosting 1.29 g of S corresponding to 56% S content.18 It was difficult for these 2D powdery carbons to fabricate high capacity S cathodes with 470 wt% and areal loading over 3–4 mg cm 2 that can surpass the energy density of existing LIBs. Increasing the S percentage and areal loading for the fabrication of dense and thick electrodes can degrade the performance and deteriorate the utilization and efficiency of S. This is due to the enhanced over-potential arising from a low conductivity and aggregation of S, the long diffusion pathway and tortuosity, and huge volume variations. In order to achieve both high loading and utilization of S, diverse chemical strategies for modifying the surface chemistry and structure of 2D nanomaterials have been exploited. The surface modification leads to the high loading and homogeneous distribution of S, while providing strong and large contact area with the conductive 2D surface. For instance, carboxylated graphene/S composites, which were synthesized through a reverse water-inoil micro-emulsion process, exhibited a high S content up to 94 wt% and uniform distribution on the micropores.87 Even at high S loading of 8 mg cm 2, this composite deposited on carbon cloth showed a high capacity of 1256 mA h g 1. S could be immobilized on the GO surface through C–S and O–S bonding and this S-immobilized GO was assembled into a binder- and current collector-free 2D paper for a high S loading. However, the specific capacity and cyclic stability were not sufficiently high because of a low S utilization (75%) and the dissolution of LiPS, respectively.
About 80% volume expansion is another obstacle for high S loading.6,19 Thus, the hierarchical architecting of 2D nanomaterials could create inter-network conducting channels for facile ion access and offer huge free space for high S loading and buffering volume. Self-standing 3D graphene foams or monoliths can avoid using a binder and current collector while achieving high loading and utilization of S and effective volume expansion.88 3D graphene foam derived from sacrificial Ni foam (Fig. 3A) revealed a high areal capacity of 13.4 mA h cm 2 with an areal S loading (70 wt% of S) of 10.1 mg cm 2. The gravimetric capacity was around 1370 mA h g 1 (80% of S utilization) at 0.30 A g 1 and 450 mA h g 1 at 6 A g 1, suggesting a high rate capability. The electrode delivered charge– discharge stability over 1000 cycles with only 0.07% decay per cycle as shown in Fig. 3E. A self-supported carbon yolk cell was also proposed to provide high conductive channels with total surface area and pore volume of 2296 m2 g 1 and 2.1 cm3 g 1, respectively, for the maximum utilization of S as shown in Fig. 3B.89 The microporous surface area and volume were reported as 454 m2 g 1 and 0.87 cm3 g 1, respectively. The resulting yolk-cell structure was associated with a homogeneous S distribution with packing density of 10 mg cm 2, areal capacity of 11.4 mA h cm 2, and cyclic stability over 500 cycles with capacity decay of 0.040% per cycle. Approximately 54% capacity retention was observed when the rates increased from 0.1 to 4C, suggesting a high rate capability. However, the high micropore volume and associated surface area resulted in a high E/S ratio of 15 mL mg 1, which would cause low energy density. As another example of hierarchical architecture, rGO microchannels were vertically grown to form a 3D wood-like architecture with a surface area of 731 m2 g 1, thereby achieving a very high S loading of 21.3 mg cm 2 and low E/S ratio of 7.5 mL mg 1 (Fig. 3C).90 Yeon et al. demonstrated radially oriented open-porous spherical graphene architectures using a spray-frozen assembly and ozonation method as shown in Fig. 3D.91 The hierarchically structured composites (78.2 wt% of S content) exhibited a high specific capacity of 1269.1 mA h g 1 at 0.1C having an S loading of 2 mg cm 2 with E/S ratio of 10 mL mg 1 and stability over 500 charge–discharge cycles with a very low capacity fading of 0.08% per cycle.
Instead of a post S loading by chemical deposition or melt diffusion, an in situ growth method for S was used to fabricate a highly S-loaded electrode. This 3D structured rGO exhibited the capacity of 1274 mA h g 1 at 0.156 mA cm 2 and 509 mA h g 1 (or 9.0 mA h cm 2) at 7.80 mA cm 2.90 Notably, efficient S utilization (above 80%) requires more than 10 mA h cm 2 of areal capacity. 3D structured rGO with the S loadings of 7.8, 15.2, and 21.3 mg cm 2 showed the high areal capacities of 6.7, 12.6, and 15.2 mA h cm 2, respectively, as shown in Fig. 3F. The capacity retention was around 90% after 50 cycles with a capacity decay of 0.2% per cycle when S was loaded at 7.8 mg cm 2. The retention was around 74% for a high loading of 21.3 mg cm 2 with a capacity decay of 0.5% per cycle.

Moreover, it is difficult to chemically immobilize several kinds of LiPS intermediates with different polarities. 2D borophene can have strong adsorption energy with LiPSs in the range of 1 to 3 eV as demonstrated by the DFT calculation.38
Additionally, the metallic borophene–S cluster provides high electrical conductivity. Despite the promising features of borophene such as strong adsorption of LiPSs, high conductivity, and small deformation, more experiments should be performed to employ borophene as the S host for practical applications. Functional hosts and interlayers can mitigate the shuttling of LiPS, improving the re-utilization of trapped S, and preventing the dissolution of long-chain LiPSs through strong polar–polar interactions. For instance, highly conductive metals decorated onto the 2D graphene surface provided high electronic conductivity and a promoting effect for the maximum utilization of S.100 A Pt-decorated graphene/S electrode with S loading of 2 mg cm 2 and E/S ratio of 5 mL mg 1 exhibited the discharge capacity of 1100 mA h g 1 at 0.1C, which was almost 40% higher than that of Pt-free one.100 The use of catalyst can enhance the rate kinetics and thus, maintain high S utilization at low E/S ratio of 5 mL mg 1. Du et al.101 synthesized monodisperse Co atoms embedded N-doped graphene (Co–N/G) with 90 wt% S content, S loading of 6.0 mg cm 2, and E/S ratio of 12 mL mg 1. The Co–N–C coordination center served as a bi-functional electro-catalyst to trigger the surface-mediated reaction of LiPSs, thereby achieving the gravimetric and areal specific capacities of 1210 mA h g 1 (0.72% S utilization) and 5.1 mA h cm 2, respectively, with capacity retention over 100 cycles. Wu et al.102 synthesized a 2D carbon Co/N corrugated adenine derivative having a specific surface area and pore volume of 526 m2 g 1 and 0.46 cm3 g 1, respectively with an average pore size of 3.7 nm. The lithiophilic– sulfiphilic (Co/N) sites enhanced the conversion kinetics for polysulfides, while the 2D conductive matrix facilitated the homogeneous distribution of S/Li2S deposits and strong adsorbability. Taking advantage of the synergistic effects, the Li–S cell with a high S loading of 9.7 mg cm 2 exhibited high gravimetric and areal specific capacities of 1290 mA h g 1 and 6 mA h cm 2 along with long term cycling stability over 600 cycles. However, the high pore volume with small pore size required excess electrolyte to fill the pores at a high E/S ratio of 15 mL mg 1.
Although there is controversy about their exact role as reaction promoters, some 2D nanomaterials such as TMDCs, TMNs, TMPs, TMSs, TMDCs, LDHs, MOFs, and MXene exhibited a strong affinity with LiPSs and kinetically promoted their transformation into Li2S2/Li2S.

Thus, the functional 2D nanomaterials are expected to improve the efficiency of S-containing cathodes.

2 ) on the TMO surface as shown in Fig. 4B(a). As the reduction proceeded, the thiosulfates anchored the newly formed long-chain LiPSs to form polythionate (O3S–Sx 2–SO3)

Mn4+ ions predominantly existing in the layers of the edge-sharing octahedral sites of 2D MnO2 were simultaneously reduced to Mn 2+ ions during this reduction process (Fig. 4B(b)). Thus, the LiPSs remained anchored on the TMO surface through the redox mediator (of thiosulfate and polythionate)43,103 and their shuttling was inhibited. The S electrodes including MnO2 exhibited a reversible capacity of 1300 mA h g 1 at 0.05C with S content of 75% and cyclic stability over 2000 cycles.103 The formation of thiosulfate and polythionate was also observed for VO2.

2 g 1 and 0.30 cm3 g 1, respectively, and thus, the S content was around 38 wt%. The applications of TMPs in Li–S batteries were less as compared to the corresponding TMOs or TMDCs.45 However, TMPs have an advantage in terms of metallic characteristics or even superconductivity. The lower activation potentials for TMPs were due to a low charge transfer resistance to decompose Li2S. The adsorption energies of Li2S on Ni2P@NPC, Co2P@NPC, and Fe2P@NPC surfaces were 3.70, 4.00, and 5.34 eV, much higher than 0.37 and 0.94 eV of pure carbon and N-doped carbon, respectively. The dissociation energy of Li2S on the TMPs surface ranged from 0.60 to 0.75 eV, however, pristine carbon and N doped carbon had 1.86 and 1.52 eV, respectively. These results are associated with the polar interactions and rapid redox kinetics of Li2S on the TMPs surfaces. Cheng et al. reported an MOF-derived Ni2P nanoporous composite (Ni2P/NC), where the porous conductive 3D skeleton
carbon provides accelerating electron transport and Ni2P offers chemical interactions to avoid LiPSs shuttling.109 The as-designed cell exhibited a specific capacity of 918 mA h g 1 at 0.2C with a high S loading of 4.6 mg cm 2 (61.92% of S content) and enhanced cycling stability over 300 cycles with 0.08% decay per cycle.
2D TMDCs have been investigated as functional hosts and interlayers, considering previous research into the desulfurization reaction catalysts associated with strong sulfiphilic capability. Sulfiphilic CoS2 clusters were hybridized with graphene to fabricate the CoS2–graphene composite with 15 wt% of CoS2. 44 This composite revealed a high capacity of 1368 mA h g 1 at 0.5C with S content of 75 wt% and areal S loading of 0.4 mg cm 2, exhibiting stable 2000 charge–discharge cycles with 0.34% capacity decay per cycle. Around 60% capacity improvement by CoS2, relative to the graphene–S electrode, with cyclic stability was attributed to the charge transfer from the conductive matrix to adsorbed LiPSs accelerating the polysulfide redox kinetics as shown in Fig. 4F. WS2 nanosheets hybridized with carbon showed only 7% S dissolution into an electrolyte solution after 10 hours, whereas the pristine carbon electrode revealed around 47% dissolution.110 The Li–S cell exhibited good cyclic stability over 1500 cycles (with around 90% S utilization and 2 mg cm 2 of areal loading). As demonstrated by the computation study, the binding energy of WS2 with low order LiPSs was higher than that for high order Li2S8 and S. Given the higher capacity of low order LiPS as compared to the high order LiPS in the discharging curve, the better adsorption of the former justified the excellent performance of WS2.
The crystalline phase of 2D TMDC affected LiPS redox kinetics. The S deficiency in the 2H phase of MoS2 nanoflakes offered electron-rich sites for participation in LiPS conversion and promoted the redox kinetics (Fig. 4G).64 The S-deficient MoS2–rGO (MoS2 x–rGO) revealed a pair of sharp redox peaks with narrow peak separations in the symmetric cell using Li2S6 as the electrolyte. In contrast, the MoS2–rGO symmetric cell exhibited broadened peaks with widened peak separation as compared to those of MoS2 x–rGO. The S electrode having 1.5 mg cm 2 of areal loading with only 4 wt% of MoS2 x–rGO delivered the specific capacity of 1310 mA h g
1 at 0.2C and 63.1% of initial capacity at 8C, showing long term cyclic stability for 600 cycles with a capacity fading rate of 0.083% per cycle at 0.5C. However, the Li–S cell was fabricated with a very high E/S ratio of 430 mL mg 1.
Zhang et al. synthesized novel hollow Ni/Fe LDH polyhedrons as an S host to enhance the performance of Li–S batteries.49 Polyhedral Ni/Fe LDH shells were formed on MIL-88A by treating with Ni(NO3)2 and urea as revealed in Fig. 4H. The specific surface area decreased from 104.3 m2 g 1 to 3.6 m2 g 1 when the S content was 70 wt% (2 mg cm 2 of areal loading), suggesting that most pores and internal voids were occupied by S. The Ni/Fe LDH/S delivered a specific capacity of 1050 mA h g 1 at 0.1C with an areal specific capacity of 2.47 mA cm 2, and it was retained at around 60% at 2C. In LDH, the combination of sulfiphilic sites and the hollow architecture led to the prolonged cyclic stability of 1000 cycles with 0.04% capacity decay per cycle. sections.heading: 3.3 2D materials as analogues of S active materials
sections.text:
The 2D TMDCs play the role of active materials, as well as functional host materials.76,118–123 This section focuses on 2D active TMDCs consisting of group VI metals (Mo and W) and dichalcogenide anions X2 (X = S). For instance, MoS2, when used as the LIB anode, undergoes intercalation and conversion reactions in the potential range of 0–3 V.118–120 Li insertion into the interlayer of MoS2 during the first discharge is accompanied by a phase transition from the 2H to 1T structure of LixMoS2 at a voltage plateau of around
1.1 V vs. Li/Li+. The intercalation reaction is reversible as described in Fig. 6A.76
The LixMoS2 is further converted to Mo atom and Li2S at around 0.5 V vs. Li/Li+. However, this conversion reaction is irreversible and the Li2S is converted to S during the first charging process because Mo cannot be oxidized to 3 V.76,118–120 Hence, Li2S and S became the sole redox couple, which is quite similar to the Li–S battery as described in Section 4. MoS2 was used as the anode in the potential range of 0.8 to 3 V and 0.05 to 3 V in order to understand the redox mechanism.76 The symmetric plateaus in the charge and discharge profiles suggested reversible reactions in the potential of 0.8 to 3 V as shown in Fig. 6B(a). The discharge capacity at the second cycle was 175 mA h g 1, which was retained as 135 mA h g 1 with 100% coulombic efficiency after 100 cycles on decreasing the cut-off voltage to 0.05 V, a reduction peak at 0.5 V, related to the irreversible conversion reaction of LixMoS2 - Mo + Li2S, appeared in the first discharge curve. During successive discharge cycles, the peaks at 1.0 and 0.5 V disappeared with the appearance of two peaks at 1.1 and 1.9 V. Moreover, the peak at 2.3 V was well discernible in the charging process and was associated with the formation of S. The redox peaks at around 1.1 and 1.9 V in the cathodic scan might be contributed by intermediate LiPSs because they appeared only from the second cycle. The specific capacity at the second discharge was 790 mA h g 1. However, the plateaus in both discharge and charge processes disappeared after 50 cycles and thus, the capacity of only 180 mA h g 1 was maintained after 100 cycles. The capacity fading was due to the dissolution of LiPSs in the electrolyte. Moreover, Oakes et al. demonstrated that a local strain of around 1% in vertically stacked carbon–MoS2, which was associated with the lattice mismatch between the carbon and MoS2, facilitated Li insertion to sustain direct conversion at 2.3 V vs. Li/Li+.122 Fang et al. synthesized a graphene-like WS2 by a solid-state reaction of elemental W and S for LIB anode.121

sections.heading: 4. 2D materials-modified separators/ interlayers
sections.text: With respect to the intrinsic drawbacks of Li–S batteries, rationally introducing 2D materials to construct functional separators/interlayers provides a feasible and straightforward way to achieve highperformance Li–S batteries by retarding soluble LiPSs migration and regulating lithium plating behavior.124–129 Although both modified separators and free-standing interlayers are discussed in this section, the thickness of the modifying layer on conventional separator is commonly thinner as compared to that of the free-standing interlayer. This can potentially facilitate higher energy density and better rate performance.

sections.heading: 4.1 Separator/interlayer modifications for cathode enhancement
sections.text:
Generally, the cycling stability of the S cathode is severely hindered by the insulating nature of S and the uncontrollable polysulfide shuttling reaction, which directly leads to poor rate performance and low S utilization. Based on the literature, intentionally incorporating 2D materials onto routine separators or the fabricated interlayers mainly serve in three roles: (1) to enhance the cathode conductivity for better S re-activation; (2) to mitigate the polysulfide diffusion via physical barrier or chemical interactions; (3) to promote accelerated LiPSs conversion kinetics. These functions can be achieved by incorporating 2D materials solely or using their composites.
4.1.1 2D materials acting as functional layers in separators/interlayers. 2D nanocarbon-based materials are under intensive investigation due to their superior structural and electrical conduction properties, both of which are considered to favor a more stable S cathode with higher utilization and faster kinetics. Typically, graphene exhibits large specific surface area and abundant pore structure to physically trap the soluble LiPSs and high electrical conductivity to re-utilize the ‘‘dead’’ S species.124 Based on this consideration, a mesoporous cellular graphene framework-modified Janus separator was constructed by Peng et al.125 On applying such a ‘‘two-face’’ Janus configuration, a very high areal capacity of 5.5 mA h cm 2 with high S content of 80% and areal loading amount of 5.3 mg cm 2 can be achieved.125 Zhou et al. pioneered the configuration design and proposed a GCC/S + G separator sandwich structure. With graphene simultaneously acting as
the current collector and separator modifying layer, the electrode can provide rapid ion- and electron-transport pathways, accommodate S volumetric expansion, store and reuse migrating LiPSs to alleviate the shuttling effect (Fig. 7A).126
The introduction of heteroatoms, i.e. P, N, S, O, and functional groups can considerably enhance the chemical interactions of pristine graphene with the soluble polysulfide species, thereby reducing the sharp irreversible S loss caused by the shuttle reaction.124 Huang et al. constructed a permselective GO membrane to alleviate the self-discharge behavior of Li–S batteries.130 The carboxyl groups anchored on the GO sheets acting as ion-hopping sites for positively charged species (Li+) and rejected the transportation of negatively charged species (Sn
2 ) due to electrostatic repulsion (Fig. 7B). In addition, rGO, with residual functional groups and reasonable electrical properties, is reported to be an effective modifying material.131,132 Xing et al. incorporated an N,S co-doped graphene sponge interlayer into Li–S batteries.127 With the restricted LiPSs dissolution and decreased charge transfer resistance, the S cathode can demonstrate a stable cycling performance and a superior rate performance with high discharge capacity of 829.4 mA h g 1 at 6C. A sulfonated rGO (SRGO) interlayer was fabricated to physically block the migration of polysulfide and anchor LiPS by the electronegative sulfonic group concurrently (Fig. 7C).128 Benefiting from this SRGO interlayer, the prototype battery exhibited a high reversible discharge capacity of more than 1300 mA h g 1 and good capacity retention of 802 mA h g 1 after 250 cycles at a 0.5C rate. Besides, Wu et al. investigated a light-weight boron-functionalized rGO (B-rGO) layer with the areal loading of the layer at 0.2–0.3 mg cm 2, where both stronger binding ability towards polysulfides and enhanced electrical conductivity were achieved.129 Pei et al. demonstrated graphene nanosheet-encapsulated N-doped hollow porous carbon on a PP separator to fabricate high-performance Li–S batteries.133 The high surface area, N-doped, 2D close-packed laminar structure (areal density of 0.07 mg cm 2 and thickness of 0.9 mm) was able to design a thin and light-weight separator. The as-fabricated S/carbon block electrode (S loading of 3.5 mg cm 2 and S content of 64 wt%) by the slurry coating method revealed a specific capacity of 990 mA h g 1 at 0.2C and stability over 500 cycles (88.6%) at 1C. In order to improve the S loading, the self-supported CNT/S electrode was fabricated, avoiding the use of binder. Even at a high S loading of 12.1 mg cm 2, high areal capacity of 16 mA h cm 2 and cyclic stability around 100 cycles were revealed. Good cyclic stability over 400 cycles and an areal capacity of 12 mA h cm 2 (1183 mA h g 1 at 0.2C) were achieved when the S loading was adjusted to 6 mg cm 2 (70 wt% of S content). The E/S ratio is largely dependent on the structure of the cathode. The E/S ratio was optimized to be 20 mL mg 1, which was higher than 9 mL mg 1 for the slurry-coated S/carbon block cathode. Aside from carbon-based materials, other 2D materials with unique properties were attempted in this field. An MXenefunctionalized separator was designed. The presence of an interlayer between the cathode and anode can absorb more electrolyte. Therefore, a high electrolyte to S (E/S) ratio is required. The presence of an extra interlayer would increase the mass, sacrificing the energy density of the cell. Wu et al. developed a thin layer of 3D MoS2 nanospheres with thickness of 3 mm, which was constructed by depositing 2D MoS2 nanosheets on the S cathode by a doctor blade followed by drying at 60 1C under vacuum for 8 h.140 The as-designed cell revealed a gravimetric specific capacity of 1200 mA h g 1 at 0.2C, charge–discharge cycle stability of 600 cycles (0.06% capacity decay per cycle), and areal capacity of 3.96 mA h cm 2 along with S loading of 4 mg cm 2 and E/S ratio of 15 mL mg 1. Assembling MoS2 nanosheets into a 3D structure provides abundant active edge sites and a large contact surface, which effectively prevent LiPSs shuttling as well as fast Li+ diffusion, as justified by the expanded (002) interlayer of MoS2 for sufficient electrolyte wettability.
4.1.2 Composite 2D materials-modified separators/interlayers. The interactions between heteroatoms and polysulfide remain insufficient with binding energy below 2 eV, which is
considerably lower than that of inorganic oxides, sulfides, nitrides and carbides.135,141 A straightforward consideration is to combine carbon-based materials with other superior 0D, 1D and 2D materials to render a synergistic effect.142,143
2D + 0D. 2D graphene and graphene derivatives combined with 0D inorganic particles have been applied to fabricate advanced separators/interlayers. Xiao et al. developed a graphene/TiO2 composite interlayer, where the porous graphene afforded an additional electrically conductive network, and physically trapped S and polysulfide; TiO2 further chemically suppressed the dissolution of polysulfide and alleviated the undesirable shuttle effect (Fig. 8A).144 The cell with the graphene/TiO2 interlayer delivered a high specific capacity of E1040 mA h g 1 over 300 cycles at 0.5C. Ultralow capacity degradation rates of 0.01% and 0.018% per cycle over 1000 cycles were achieved at 2 and 3C, respectively. Functional separators modified with 2D graphene/0D Li4Ti5O12,
145 2D rGO/0D MoP146 and 2D GO/0D LiF147 composites were also explored to inhibit the LiPSs shuttling. Song et al. proposed a tri-layer graphene/PP/Al2O3 dual-functional separator.
148 Graphene was coated on one side of the PP separator, which functions as a conductive layer and an electrolyte reservoir that allows for rapid electron and ion transport. Al2O3 particles were coated on the other side to further enhance the thermal stability and safety of the separator (Fig. 8B). Sun et al. developed 3D hierarchical N-doped carbon nanosheet/MoP nanocrystal hollow nanospheres (MoP@C/N HCSs), which were coated onto a separator and the corresponding thickness was adjusted to 5 mm.149 The MoP@C/N HCSs acted as the LiPSs immobilizer providing strong physical and chemical trapping interactions,

2D + 1D. 2D materials cooperated well with 1D materials such as nanotubes and nanofibers to display structural synergy. Zhang et al. adopted 2D GO and 1D oxidized carbon nanotubes (o-CNT) as the raw materials to fabricate a thin coating on the separator by a facile spray method.150 The 2D structure of GO facilitated the formation of a continuous film with a small amount of material, while the o-CNT served as the spacers to mitigate the tight stacking of the GO sheets. A porous GO/ carbon nanotube (CNT) composite interlayer with 1.1 mg cm 2 of areal loading and B30 mm of thickness was also described by Huang et al.151 In addition, Jeong et al. proposed a bifunctional separator of 1T exfoliated 2D MoS2@CNT-coated Celgard. 152 The metallic 1T phase MoS2 sheets were prepared by a facile and highly controllable electrochemical exfoliation method. The optimized 1T MoS2@CNT bifunctional separator in a tandem configuration delivered an excellent polysulfide trapping and electron transfer. A hollow carbon nanofiber (HCNF)@mesoporous d-MnO2 nanosheet-coated separator was prepared by Lai et al., where the bifunctional HCNF provided excellent electrical conductivity and physical confinement of polysulfides, while the porous d-MnO2 coated on the wall of HCNF provided more adsorption sites for polysulfides due to the large surface area (Fig. 8C).153 Guo et al. used Ti3C2Tx with positively charged polyethyleneimine (PEI) functionalized CNT (lithiophilic) as an inter-linked S host and antifouling separator.154 The voltage hysteresis gap of 120 mV was smaller as compared to 228 and 164 mV for Ti3C2Tx and Ti3C2Tx@CNT, respectively, at 0.05 mV. The dynamic inter-linked cathode of metallic conductive MXene and the CNT pillars provided dual polar sites to boost the redox kinetics. The separator designed by metallic/sulfiphilic nanosheets and lithiophilic pillars acted as an ‘‘antifouling interface’’ to prevent the electrical insulation arising from the accumulation of Li2S/Li2S2. The resultant cell with S loading of 5.8 mg cm 2 and E/S ratio of 12 mL mg 1 achieved an outstanding areal capacity of 7.1 mA h cm 2.
Composites with other 2D materials. The combinations of 2D materials with other 2D materials, polymers, or multi-component composites were investigated. Peng et al. proposed a cooperative interface for highly efficient Li–S batteries through the combination of 2D nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) and 2D multi-metallic layered hydroxides.155 The nanosized ‘‘sulfiphilic’’ LDHs and mesoporous ‘‘lithiophilic’’ NG were assembled rationally with cooperation in providing bifunctional chemical *Li and *S binding, reinforcing the trapping ability towards polysulfides, and promoting the formation of Li2S (Fig. 9A). A thin layer of this LDH@NG film on the separator can increase a high S loading up to 4.3 mg cm 2, a high initial capacity of 1078 mA h g 1 at 1 mA cm 2 and good retention of 800 mA h g 1 after 100 cycles. GO, with excellent 2D stacking structure, can serve as building blocks in polymer modification layers. Zhuang et al.156 reported a ternary layered separator with a
macroporous PP matrix layer, GO barrier layer, and Nafion retarding layer. The ultrathin GO layer (0.0032 mg cm 2) blocked the macropores of the PP matrix, and a dense ion-selective Nafion layer (0.05 mg cm 2) was attached to GO as a retarding layer to suppress the crossover of S-containing species (Fig. 9B).
A highly porous polyacrylonitrile/GO composite nanofiber separator was fabricated by Zhu et al.157 Excellent barrier effects can be expected from the relatively high binding energy between –CRN and Li2S/LiPSs and the electrostatic interactions between GO and the negatively charged species (Sn
2 ). The compositing of 2D materials with multiple components was investigated by Kong et al., who developed ultrathin MnO2/ GO/CNT (G/M@CNT) interlayers with thickness of 2 mm and areal density of 0.104 mg cm 2 depositing MnO2 nanoparticles and GO sheets on super-aligned CNT films (Fig. 9C).158 The synergetic effect of the G/M@CNT interlayer enabled the production of Li–S cells with high S content (60–80 wt%), low capacity decay rate (0.029% per cycle over 2500 cycles at 1C), high rate performance (747 mA h g 1 at 10C), and low selfdischarge rate with high capacity retention (93.0% after 20 d rest). Besides, 2D graphene and GO with superior structural stability also serve as a mechanical skeleton to accommodate other novel functional materials.159,160 Fan et al. introduced a positively charged, functionalized BN (FBN)–graphene (Fig. 9D).39 The FBN–graphene hybrid layer (40 wt% of FBN) was coated on the CNT/S cathode (with S content of 70%) at a thickness of 1 mm. The positively charged amino groups on FBN attracted the negatively charged LiPSs, achieving good cyclic stability over 1000 cycles with a very low decay rate of 0.0037% and S utilization of 66%. Ni–Co-LDHs-anchored carbon paper (Ni–Co-LDHs/CP) was transformed into nanoparticle-stacked metal nitride on CP (N-LDH-400) by annealing at 400 1C under a constant flowing NH3.
161 The product was used as the interlayer with a thickness of 235 mm of rGO–S cathode. The cell with N-LDH-400 interlayer exhibited higher specific capacity of 1001.8 mA h g 1 at 0.2C as compared to 981 and 956 mA h g 1 for the Ni–Co-LDHs/CP interlayer and only rGO–S. A long-term cyclic stability of 800 cycles was achieved with the Ni–Co-LDHs/CP interlayer, which confined the LiPSs by both physical and chemical interactions. For the S cathode, a complicated solid–liquid–solid transition reaction occurred during the charge or discharge process. As shown in a typical discharge procedure, elemental S accepts electrons and is primarily reduced to soluble long-chain polysulfides (Li2Sx, 8 r x r 4), which are further transformed into solid-phase Li2S/Li2S in the second-stage reduction. Reverse processes can be observed during a charging procedure. Two critical issues remain in degrading the capacity and cycle life of the S cathode, namely, the poor electrical conduction of S/Li2S and the shuttle effect brought by the soluble polysulfides. The former strongly induces a low utilization of S, while the latter further contributes to a rapid capacity decay of the cathode and severe corrosion of the Li metal anode. To implement a facile electron transfer for the sufficient conversion of S species in the cathode, additionally incorporating materials with superior conductivity and large surface area need to be strongly considered.124,132 Trapping polysulfide via physical confinement and chemical adsorption is

The Li-ion conducting barrier can be an effective solution to simply restrict the long-chain LiPSs dissolution.165,166 Moy et al. used lithiated cobalt oxide (LCO) as a mixed conduction membrane (MCM) to suppress the LiPSs shuttling.165 The nonporous electronically conducting MCM has been flanked between two porous insulating polypropylene membranes, followed by soaking in electrolyte, and the designed threelayer composite was used as modified separator. The Li–S cell
having the MCM membrane and S loading of 5.5 mg cm 2 showed the capacity retention of 69% after 200 cycles at 0.05C along with the coulombic efficiency of 95%. The cell without membrane revealed capacity retention and coulombic efficiency of 42% and 76%, respectively. The initial shuttle current was measured to be 85% lower for the cell having the membrane as compared to the cell without the membrane. The internal resistance of the cell remained unaffected as the MCM membrane provided rapid Li+ ion transportation. The nonporous MCM prevented the long-chain LiPSs from being diffused from the S-electrode, while selectively allowing the transportation of Li+ ions through a mixed conduction intercalation/de-intercalation mechanism. One weakness of the unique approach is the use of additional LCO, which will increase the cell cost as well as reduce the overall energy density. However, these disadvantages are offset by the benefit of the improved life cycle.

A highly lithium-ion conductive lithium fluoride (LiF)/GO modifying layer with a high lithium-ion diffusion coefficient value of 1.5 10 7 cm2 s 1 was reported.177 GO possesses the advantages of high elastic modulus and desirable mechanical strength to accommodate the brittle LiF. The ability of this LiF/GO layer to prevent lithium dendrite growth was confirmed by the flat Li morphology after 50 cycles.
Regulating the deposition direction and morphology by a separator modification is a facile strategy to circumvent dendrite piercing. Liu et al. coated the separator with a Li+-immobilized functional nanocarbon (FNC).167 The Li deposition on FNC was directed from the separator to the anode surface, which is opposite to the direction of the routine deposition from the anode to the separator. The low-dimensional dendritic deposits were transformed into a higher-dimensional Li metal layer, which efficiently prevented cell shorting. The immobilized Li ions in the functional groups of FNC were reduced to Li-metal atoms, serving as ‘‘seeds’’ for Li-dendrite formation during plating. A Li/LiFePO4 coin cell with this FEC layer coated on the separator achieved a long stable cycle life (4800 cycles with 80% capacity retention) and improved efficiency (497%).
In addition to the anode surface, BN can be coated onto a separator to mediate Li deposition. From aspects of its superior thermal stability, Liu et al. integrated thermally stable BN nanosheets into a polyvinylidene fluoride–hexafluoropropene (PVDF–HFP) matrix via an advanced extrusion-based 3D printing technique.168 The BN/PVDF–HFP hybrid separator offers a uniform thermal distribution interface and enables homogeneous Li nucleation, which decreases the risk of cell short circuit and fires caused by the thermal runaway of the routine separator, therefore realizing a safe Li metal battery.

sections.heading: 5. Practical required parameters
sections.text:
In order to achieve a commercial Li–S battery, the gravimetric energy density must be higher as compared to the state-of-theart LIBs. Additionally, the cost per kW h of energy should be less than that of the present LIBs. The rational design of high energy density Li–S batteries depends on the S cathode, with excellent electrochemical performance (high S utilization, reversible redox kinetics, good electrochemical stability, and elongated cycle life) and practically essential cell parameters (high S loading, high S content, and low E/S). The aforementioned studies confirmed that there are very limited examples considering all of those parameters. For instance, there are several
studies that could improve the specific capacity, S loading, S utilization, and S content, as well as accelerate the rate kinetics using the reaction promoter as discussed in Section 3. In contrast, there are very few investigations that achieved low E/S of o3.0 mL mg 1, having the S loading of 46 mg cm 2 to satisfy the practical requirements. Moreover, there was tremendous interest in investigating the cell fabrication process, total cost, and self-discharge of Li–S cell. Hagen et al. examined the effect of the E/S ratio using a binder-free vertically aligned CNT electrode with S loading of 6.6 mg cm 2.169 They concluded that the E/S ratio has to be 47 to achieve the current density of 0.67 mA cm 2. Sun et al. systematically investigated the effect of the E/S ratio on different S loadings in a range of current densities.170 The S electrode with S loading of 10.59 mg cm 2 and E/S ratio of 3.4 mL mg 1 achieved low specific capacity of around 250 mA h g 1 at 0.1 mA cm 2, failing to show reasonable performance above 2.0 mA cm 2. The electrode having S loading of 10.01 mg cm 2 and E/S ratio of 7.5 mL mg 1 exhibited a specific capacity of 1000 mA h g 1 at 0.1 mA cm 2, which can sustain the capacity of 200 mA h g 1 at high current density of 4 mA cm 2. The utilization of 2D materials as hosts can afford fast conducting channels to lower the amount of electrolyte. Hence, it is expected that the introduction of a reaction promoter based on conductive 2D materials can overcome the sluggish redox kinetics to afford a low E/S ratio, which would result in achieving high energy density and low cost of the Li–S battery. Lin et al. demonstrated the fabrication of the S electrode through the roomtemperature process, the dry mixing of holey graphene and S and the subsequent ball milling and dry-pressing.171 Accordingly, this binder-free S electrode achieved the areal and gravimetric capacities of 11.9 mA h cm 2 and 1291 mA h g 1, respectively, with an areal S loading of 9.2 mg cm 2, E/S ratio of 6.7 mL mg 1, and 80% S content.
The US Advanced Battery Consortium estimated the selling price to be US$150 kW h 1 for a mass-produced (25 000 units) 40 kW h battery pack.172,173 Currently, the LIBs battery technology enables a pack-level price of around US$500–600 kW h 1. Hagen et al. anticipated the cost of the material of Li–S 18650 cell as $70–130 kW h 1 when a S loading of 6 mg cm 2 and E/S ratio of 3 mL mg 1 were achieved using CNT as the host material (Fig. 10A).172 The electrochemical instability of the Li–S battery is another consideration in achieving the practical parameters to accomplish the superior Li–S battery technology relative to other batteries. The Li–S battery suffers from a severe self-discharge, where 450% can be discharged in a month when the cell is at rest. Therefore, the self-discharge of Li–S batteries can be a more serious issue in comparison to Li-ion batteries, which go through a self-discharge of o3% per month. Despite this technical challenge, only a few studies have focused on the self-discharge of Li–S cells to date. More attention should be paid to understanding the static electrochemical instability (or self-discharge) during cell resting to compete with the state-of-the-art LIBs. sections.heading: 6. Summary and outlook
sections.text:
We have addressed the recent progress in the applications of 2D nanomaterials into cathode and separator components of Li–S batteries and how to resolve technical issues associated with the redox chemistry and material properties of the S cathode. By fully utilizing the intrinsic properties and controllable surface chemistries of 2D nanomaterials and further deriving extrinsic properties from the hierarchical architecture and hybridization, they demonstrate their promising potentials as versatile building units to be used as active materials, hosts, protection layers, conductive additives, and reaction promoters. However, the development of practical Li–S batteries that can satisfy the requirements for both performance and safety is still an ongoing process.
First, the utilization and efficiency of active materials such as Li and S should be improved on a practical level as electrodes. At least 80% of S utilization and 6 mA h cm 2 of areal capacity should be achieved with high reversibility. Second, the target performances of active materials should be achieved on a practical level by controlling the thicknesses and areal loadings of both electrodes. For instance, S cathodes need to meet the aforementioned requirements, such as high utilization and efficiency at 470 wt% of S content, E/S ratio of 3 mL mg 1, and areal loading of more than 6 mg cm 2, so that Li–S batteries can achieve an energy density of 600 W h L 1, greater than that of LIBs.179 There is no report to date about S electrodes that can satisfy all target parameters such as 70% S loading, E/S ratio of 3 mL mg 1, 6 mg cm 2 areal S loading in the cathode, 80% utilization of S active materials, and long term stability. 2D host materials, such as 2D graphene and porous carbon achieved areal S loadings of 8 to 10 mg cm 2 (with S content above 70% and S utilization of 70–80%). The physical confinement of LiPSs is usually limited by short-term cycling of a few hundred cycles. Additionally, the high micropore volume requires a large amount of electrolyte for a high E/S ratio. 2D materials such as TMOs, TMNs and TMDCs inhibit LiPS shuttling and improve the reaction kinetics, achieving 80–90% of S utilization, E/S ratio of 5–10 mL mg 1, and over 2000 cyclability with a decay rate of 0.04 to 0.1% per cycle. The polar 2D materials reduced the self-discharge behavior, adsorbing the LiPSs during the resting time. However, the presence of additional reaction promoters at 10–20 wt% of active materials restricts the S content to 60–70 wt%, areal S loading to 1–2 mg cm 2, and areal specific capacity to 2–5 mA h cm 2. Cathodes having a TMDC interlayer can achieve S utilization of around 86% with areal S loading of around 4 mg cm 2 and charge–discharge stability for more than 500 cycles. The interlayer
with thickness of 5–50 mm provides additional weight, which results in lowering the energy density. At least 80% of the S utilization and 6 mA h cm 2 of the areal capacity should be achieved with high reversibility. It is expected that a 2D carbon host without microporosity (for high S loading) and very thin and low-density TMO or TMDC interlayers (for enhanced life cycle, S utilization, and low E/S ratio) can be applied in the design of the Li–S battery cathode to achieve the target energy density.
Thus, as-developed Li–S batteries with 2.2 V of cell voltage can have greater energy and capacity than those of the current LIB batteries. Third, the electrode performance should be evaluated using a Li–S full cell rather than half-cell. Since Li nucleation and deposition are quite different for the Li-containing anode and Li-free anode, research on Li-containing electrodes is required for the practical application of Li–S batteries. Finally, high-performance Li–S batteries should be robust and stable enough to be free from cycling efficiency and safety issues. Taking a lesson from the failure of the initial Li–metal batteries, full attention should be paid to the reactivity of Li and S to achieve both performance and safety, because they are very difficult to simultaneously control and maximize.
For the commercialization of 2D materials in the field of Li–S batteries, the cost of 2D materials should be considered as estimated in Table 1, despite the difficulty in predicting their exact values. The yields of the products prepared through existing solution exfoliation, CVD, mechanical exfoliation, and electrochemical methods are still low. The large-scale production of the newly developed 2D materials, such as MXene, borophene, and phosphorene is also a critical challenge. The scalable wet chemical synthesis is more feasible for mass production, but the quality of the final product is still not suitable. On the other hand, the synthesis methods under severe conditions such as high pressure and vacuum are subject to the high cost of equipment and low yield, despite the high quality of the final sample. Moreover, packaging technology such as passivation and encapsulation is required for stabilizing 2D materials such as MXene and phosphorene under an atmosphere of oxygen or air, thus further increasing the cost of material production. Nonetheless, the Li–S battery is still considered as a promising next-generation energy storage system beyond current Li-ion batteries, considering the cost of major Li and S active materials and their theoretical performance. For instance, the price of S is approximately $110, which is around 550 times cheaper than Co. Considering the amounts of 2D materials in the total materials of the Li–S batteries and their potential large-scale synthesis, 2D nanomaterials are believed to be strong candidates for functional hosts, protection layers, conductive additives, and reaction promoter hosts for the high-performance and cost-effective Li–S batteries.
In order to reach the last stage of practical Li–S batteries, we propose the following future research directions for 2D nanomaterials for Li–S batteries. Technologies should be developed in a hierarchical manner, ranging from materials through to electrodes and separators to cell levels. This technical improvement needs to obtain feedback from the fundamental understanding of detailed mechanisms as suggested below.

Firstly, 2D nanomaterials should be engineered at the materials level. The structure/chemistry of the as-designed 2D nanomaterials should be correlated with the electrochemical properties of Li–S batteries. Their new charge storage and failure mechanisms need to be understood in-depth, using combined computational calculations and in situ techniques. In order to achieve these goals and maximize performance, the high quality of 2D nanomaterials should be largely synthesized and delicately controlled in terms of their intrinsic structure, crystallinity, stoichiometry, and morphology. Such synthetic methods should also be scalable for the large-scale production of 2D nanomaterials required for industrial applications as discussed above.
Secondly, 2D nanomaterials should be engineered at the electrode and separator level. Intrinsically outstanding properties of 2D nanomaterials should not deteriorate during the electrode fabrication process. For instance, graphene and 2D nanomaterials can be restacked and aggregated, thus losing their large surface area and active sites. Regarding the processes of materials and electrode engineering, the extrinsic properties of the 2D nanomaterials such as transport and mechanical properties need to be maximized through optimized and/or new fabrication processes. In particular, the target utilization and efficiency of Li and S active materials that can be hosted, coated, or promoted by 2D nanomaterials for long-term cycles should be satisfied on a thick and high-loading electrode level. Since new interfaces are constructed with new electrode materials, separator modification based on 2D nanomaterials needs to be considered to resolve the critical issues of the Li anode and S cathode such as Li dendrite, electrolyte corrosion, LiPS shuttling, high ion/electron resistances, and huge volumetric and morphological changes. 2D surfaces with near-atomic or nanoscale thickness and remarkable and controllable properties of 2D nanomaterials are suitable for modifying separators as an artificial SEI layer while minimizing the volume and mass of inactive layers for the high energy densities of Li–S batteries. Considering the different interfaces and complicated chemistries associated with Li and S, ‘‘two-faced’’ Janus or functional separators are proposed by fully utilizing libraries of 2D materials. Although much progress has been achieved for the Li metal anode, these strategies are based on Li metal itself without pairing with the S cathode, neglecting the role of the shuttled LiPS from the cathode. Clear investigations into the working mechanism and regulation strategies of the Li metal anode under a LiPS-rich environment in a full cell are critically valuable for protecting the Li metal anode in the practical Li–S batteries.
Finally, 2D nanomaterials should be engineered at the cell level. Key parameters for the construction of robust and safe Li–S cells should be considered. Optimum solution compositions (of salt, solvent, and additive), optimum electrode compositions (of active material, conducting agent, and binder), cell balance between Li anode and S cathode, and the best current collector need to be found when 2D nanomaterials are applied.
The specific capacity is estimated by considering the weight of only active materials. However, the presence of conductive
agents and non-conductive binders, which is around 20% of the total electrode, reduces the total cell capacity. The minimal use of these conducting agents and binders is essential for accomplishing the highest achievable capacity on the cell-level. The use of a reaction promoter or a catalyst (additive), which is around 10–20% of the active materials to fabricate the coin cells, also reduces the S content in the electrode. Moreover, the presence of the interlayer increases the thickness, which reduces the volumetric energy density of the cell. More studies are required to estimate the proper energy density, considering the total volume and mass on the cell level. The widely used Al foil current collector contributed an additional weight of 4.86 mg cm 2 (thickness of 18 mm and density of 2.7 g cm 3), which can reduce the total capacity into 55% of the capacity obtained from S.
Cell balancing is also a crucial part of battery operation, as it has a significant effect on accessible capacity, safety, and battery life. Proper cell balancing provides the most achievable energy per use, as well as prevents over-charging/discharging and/or thermal runaway. Additionally, on the battery pack having different states of charge (SOC) of Li–S cells in series, the performance is restricted by the lowest (discharging) or highest (charging) SOC. In order to evaluate the proper balancing, it is essential to quantify the individual electrode’s performance regarding their ‘useful’ capacity, self-discharge, and SOC.
These parameters have to be investigated for practically designed cylindrical, prismatic, and pouch cell configurations. More efforts are needed to investigate realistic cell configurations, which are closer to commercial technologies using specific characterization methods. Examples include volumetric expansion measurements, absorption tomography to explore the correlation between the degradation phenomena and cell construction, and the correlation of the generated heat flow with the electrochemical/chemical processes during charge/discharge. On the basis of materials-to-system analysis, cell packaging, which projects the system-level energy density and cost, and modulation, also need to be considered for the commercialization of the Li–S battery technologies. Extra safety strategies should be developed in compliance with cell-level performance. Since the cathode is usually porous in the Li–S cell, the concentration gradients can be restricted to the cathode and interlayer during cell operation. The thickness of the cathode has to be optimized similar to the traditional LIBs (o100 mm), not sacrificing the performance and cycle life. The high S loading will have to be engineered to endure the volume exchange of the S conversion to Li2S.

metadata.abstractText: The inherent technical challenges of lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have arisen from the intrinsic redox electrochemistry occurring on the Li and S electrodes, which can significantly deteriorate the S utilization and life cycle. Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials composed of atomic or near-atomic thickness with infinite lateral dimensions have been proven to be meritorious as emerging materials for energy storage applications due to their unique structures, remarkable physical properties, and tunable surface chemistry. Herein, we argue that surface functionalization or heteroatom doping of 2D materials, hybridization with other nanostructured materials (0D quantum dots, 1D nanotubes/nanowires, and other 2D nanosheets), and finally architecting into 3D structures along with the advantages of 2D building blocks can open up new opportunities for Li–S batteries. We also focus on the future directions of Li–S batteries in the design of S cathodes and separators utilizing the intrinsic and extrinsic properties of 2D nanomaterials.
